Intro to JavaScript

						
	function helloWorld(){
		var name = "GDI";
		alert("Hello world, it's " + name + "!");
	}
	helloWorld();

Let's Get Introduced-- to JS!

What is JavaScript?

  • Cross-platform, lightweight scripting language
  • Client-side and server-side
  • Called "the language of the web" - for a reason!

---

"JavaScript can be connected to the objects of its environment to provide programmatic control over them."

Ability to interact with objects from its parent is a rare feature!

History of JS

  • 1995: At Netscape, Brendan Eich created "Mocha" in only 10 days!
  • That same year, Mocha is renamed "LiveScript" and then "JavaScript".
  • 1997: JavaScript was standardized by the ECMA as the "ECMAScript" (ES) spec.
  • 1998-2003: Various battles between browser vendors about adoption and specs! IE booo.
  • 2005: "AJAX" was coined, and the web 2.0 age begins. JavaScript renaissance!
  • 2006: jQuery 1.0 was released.
  • Netscape is now called Mozilla, makers of Firefox.
  • The name JavaScript was chosen to borrow popularity from the programming language Java. Has nothing to do with Java.
  • AJAX: Asynchronous JavaScript, allows data loading in background and out of the direct flow.
  • Standardization by ECMA allowed other browsers use the same specs.

History of JS

  • 2008ish: JavaScript isn't going away; browsers unite behind ECMA specs again.
  • 2010: Node.JS was released. Now we can use it server-side!
  • 2014-2015: Rise of "Client-side MVC frameworks"- server-side architecture (MVC) in the browser.
  • 2016: Newest ECMAScript spec (ES6) changes a lot! (But more advanced than this class.)

Let's Develop It!

Let's write your first JavaScript program!

  • Open Chrome Dev Tools
  • Click on the `Console` tab
  • Enter the following:
						
	alert('Hello World!');

Walk students through Chome Dev Tools and Console.

Explain that JS has interacted with aspects of the client (browser) and told it to do something!

Basics of Programming

  • Data Types
  • Operators
  • Comparisons
  • Variables
  • Functions (Class 2)
  • Loops & Conditionals (Class 2)

Data Types

Numbers
Integers 0, 1, 2 ... 9
Floats (decimals) 0.5, 1.618, 3.14
Strings "GDI", 'rock on', "three"
Boolean true or false
Null null
Undefined undefined
Arrays Next class!
Objects Next class!

Operators

+ Addition
- Subtraction
++ Increment (+1)
-- Decrement (-1)
* Multiplication
/ Division
% Modulus (remainder)

Comparators

! Is Not
== Equality
!= Inequality
=== Identity/strictly equal
!== Non-identity
> Greater than
>= Greater or equal
< Less than
<= Less or equal

Let's Develop It!

Experiment with Data Types,
Operators and Comparators

  • Open Chrome Dev Tools
  • Click on the `Console` tab
  • Play around!
						
	3.2 - 4
	"GDI" + "Cbus"
	6 * "six";
	( 2 + 3 ) - ( 4 * 12 )
	9 / 2
	9 % 2
	"GDI" == "gdi"
	14 >= 14

Try your own! Find any interesting results?

JavaScript Basics

Statements

Each instruction in JS is a statement, like:

console.log('Hello Class!');

After each individual statement, you must add a semicolon to end the command.

							
	console.log('I am glad to meet you.');
	console.log('Fuzzy Wuzzy Was A Bear');
If it's left off, it's up to the browser to decide what you meant.

Data Outputs

						
	// Open a popup box:
	alert('Hello World!');
	alert(2015 / 746);

	// Display a message in your console:
	console.log('Hello World!');
	console.log(14++);

	// Add something to the page:
	document.write('Hello World!');
	document.write("kittens" == "kittens");

Comments

You can leave comments in your code that won't be processed in the script.

						
	/* I can wrap long comments
	with multiple lines
	like this */
	console.log('Hello World!'); // Or short like this

Comments act as notes that people can read and computers will ignore.

						
	/* This code multiplies puppies by kitties */
	var puppies = 10;
	var kitties = 11;
	document.write(puppies * kitties);

Variables

  • When you first create a variable, it does not have a value (it is undefined).
  • You can set a value for a variable.
  • Once you give your variable a starting value, it is no longer undefined. This is called initializing the variable.
  • Variables can hold different types of information, like strings, numbers, and collections of data.
  • The value of a variable can change (be updated) later.

Naming Variables

  • The variable name is case-sensitive.
  • A new variable needs to have a unique name.
  • Variable names need to start with a letter, $, or _.
  • Variable names can only be made of letters, numbers, $, or _.

Declaring a Variable

To declare (create) a variable, just type the word "var" and the variable name.

							
	var numberOfKittens; // numberOfKittens is undefined
	var numberOfKittens = 5; // numberOfKittens is 5!

Using a Variable

Once you have created a variable, you can use it in your code. Just type the name of the variable.

						
	var numberOfKittens = 5;
	console.log(numberOfKittens);

Let's Develop It!

In your console, create a variable and give it a valid name and a value. Then, display the value.

Next, try combining a variable, a string data type, and an operator!

						
	var kittenName = 'Admiral';
	kittenName += ' Snuggles';
	console.log(kittenName); // Outputs 'Admiral Snuggles'
